message: Hi, I will ask you some questions about argumentation strength.
Please enter your ‘turker-id’ for issue handling.
Please read carefully the document on the left! When you are done reading, please click ‘continue’!

update_document.title: Alternative forms of transport to alleviate traffic congestion
update_document.body:
Recently, a great deal of attention has been paid to means of transportation. Some state that automobile is the most convenient transportation, while others assert that alternative forms of transport should be considered in view of environmental pollution. In my opinion, I strongly agree that alternative means of transportation and international laws in controlling automobiles should be introduced. In this essay, several reasons will be described carefully in the following passages.
Firstly, an increase in the number of automobiles brings about environmental pollution. Since automobile exhaust and carbon dioxides emission have bad impacts on the air, the air gets to be polluted and it causes respiratory disease of the local inhabitants. Therefore, it is crucial to alter automobiles to the other means of transportation and to legislate to control automobiles.
Secondly, an increase in the number of automobiles causes terrible traffic congestion. Once we get into the traffic jam, it forces us to waste our time for a while. What is worse, traffic congestion irritates drivers and as a result, it leads to an increase of traffic accidents. Thus, the methods to reduce the number of automobiles and to control car ownership and use should be immediately planned and implemented.
In order to solve these problems, alternative forms of transportation and international laws to control automobiles ownership and use can work effectively. With regard to the former, alternative forms which emit less carbon dioxides and gasses than automobiles are ideal. For example, rental bicycle system has been introduced in several European countries. This system is that at the corner of each district, the rental bicycles are placed and the people can ride it to the other districts with a small fee. Since bicycle expels neither carbon dioxides nor harmful gasses, it is a better form to protect environment than automobile. As for the latter point, the introduction of international laws can be also effective. For instance, there are some regulations to limit the use of automobiles by time and to allow the people possess one car only. Thus, these attempts to reduce automobiles can ease traffic congestion and environmental pollution.
In summary, even though some people claim the convenience of automobile, I would state that alternative forms of transport and international laws on controlling automobiles are necessary due to the environmental protection and the alleviation of traffic congestion.

message: Thank you! Now as the first question.
(Q1/10) How ELOQUENT (or well-presented) do you think the HIGHLIGHTED sentence is?

options.label: Mastery of English
options.description: It demonstrates mastery of English. There are no grammatical errors that distract from the meaning of the sentence. Exhibits a well thought out, flowing sentence structure that is easy to read and conveys the idea exceptionally well.

options.label: Fluency in English
options.description: It demonstrates fluency in English. If there are any grammatical or syntactical errors, their affect on the meaning is negligible. Word choice suggests a broad vocabulary.

options.label: Competence in English
options.description: It demonstrates competence in English. There might be a few errors that are noticeable but forgivable, such as an incorrect verb tense or unnecessary pluralization. Demonstrates a typical vocabulary and a simple sentence structure.

options.label: Poor English
options.description: It demonstrates poor understanding of sentence composition and/or poor vocabulary. The choice of words or grammatical errors force the reader to reread the sentence before moving on.

options.label: Minimal Eloquence
options.description: It demonstrates minimal eloquence. The sentence contains errors so severe that the sentence must be carefully analyzed to deduce its meaning.

update_document.highlight_text: alternative forms which emit less carbon dioxides and gasses than automobiles are ideal

message: (Q2/10) How SPECIFIC do you think the HIGHLIGHTED sentence is?

options.label: Elaborate, Very Specific
options.description: It is an elaborate, very specific statement. The statement contains numerical data, or a historical example from the real world. There is (1) both a sufficient qualifier indicating the extent to which the statement holds true and an explanation of why the statement is true, or (2) at least one real world example, or (3) a sufficient description of a hypothetical situation that would evoke a mental image of the situation in the minds of most readers.

options.label: A More Specific
options.description: It is a more specific statement. It is characterized by either an explanation of why the statement is true, or a qualifier indicating when/to what extent the statement is true. Alternatively, it may list examples of items that do not qualify as historical events.

options.label: Sufficiently Specific
options.description: It is a sufficiently specific statement. It simply states a relationship or a fact with little ambiguity.

options.label: Broad
options.description: It is a broad statement. A statement with hedge words and without other redeeming factors such as explicit examples, or elaborate reasoning. Additionally, there are few adjectives or adverbs.

options.label: Extremely Broad
options.description: It is an extremely broad statement. There is no underlying explanation, qualifiers, or real-world examples.

message: (Q3/10) How PERSUASIVE do you think the HIGHLIGHTED sentence is?

options.label: Very Strong, Clear
options.description: It is a very strong, clear argument. It would persuade most readers and is devoid of errors that might detract from its strength or make it difficult to understand.

options.label: Strong, Pretty Clear
options.description: It is a strong, pretty clear argument. It would persuade most readers, but may contain some minor errors that detract from its strength or understandability.

options.label: Decent, Fairly Clear
options.description: It is a decent, fairly clear argument. It could persuade some readers, but contains errors that detract from its strength or understandability.

options.label: Poor, Understandable
options.description: It is a poor, understandable argument. It might persuade readers who are already inclined to agree with it, but contains severe errors that detract from its strength or understandability.

options.label: Unclear
options.description: It is unclear what the author is trying to argue. It is unclear what the author is trying to argue or the argument is poor and just so riddled with errors as to be completely unpersuasive.

options.label: Not Making Any Argument
options.description: The author does not appear to make any argument. The author does not appear to make any argument (e.g. he may just describe some incident without explaining why it is important). It could not persuade any readers because there is nothing to be persuaded of. It may or may not contain detectable errors, but errors are moot since there is not an argument for them to interfere with.

message: Before continuing to the next question, could you please justify your answer?

It is possible that some others may answer differently, chosing a different value other than that you just chose. Please justify your judgment for the last question, with specific reasons so that the aforementioned others may change their mind and come to agree with you.
Please try to avoid a general statement ;)
And, the more specific the better - It cannot be too specific!!
Thank you so much your answer!

message: (Q5/10) How WELL the HIGHLIGHTED sentence SUMMARIZES the argument?

options.label: Perfectly
options.description: The claim summarizes the argument well and has a qualifier that indicates the extent to which the claim holds true. Claims that summarize the argument well must reference most or all of the supporting components.

options.label: Very well
options.description: The claim summarizes the argument very well by mentioning most or all of the supporting components, but does not have a qualifier indicating the conditions under which the claim holds true. Alternatively, the claim may moderately summarize the argument by referencing a minority of supporting components and contain qualifier.

options.label: Well
options.description: The claim has a qualifier clause or references a minority of the supporting components, but not both.

options.label: Poorly
options.description: The claim does not make an attempt to summarize the argument nor does it contain a qualifier clause.

options.label: Out of Scope (or simply rephrasing the major claim)
options.description: Simply rephrases the major claim or is outside scope of the major claim (argument components were annotated incorrectly: major claim could be used to support claim).
